groundings.text: The company's principal executive offices are located in California, at 2788 San Tomas Expressway, Santa Clara, which serves as the main location for Nvidia Corp's operations and management.

California is mentioned as the state where the company is incorporated, with the incorporation or organization identification number being 94-3177549, indicating the company's legal presence in the state.

The address of Nvidia Corp's principal executive offices in California is provided as 2788 San Tomas Expressway, Santa Clara, California, 95051, highlighting the company's physical presence in the state.

NVIDIA has invested over $45.3 billion in research and development since its inception, yielding inventions that are essential to modern computing. This investment has led to significant innovations, including the invention of the GPU in 1999, which sparked the growth of the PC gaming market and redefined computer graphics.

The company's introduction of the CUDA programming model in 2006 opened the parallel processing capabilities of its GPU to a broad range of compute-intensive applications, paving the way for the emergence of modern AI. This has enabled the development of various AI applications, including deep learning algorithms and neural networks.

NVIDIA's research and development efforts have also led to the introduction of new products, such as the Tensor Core GPU in 2017, built from the ground-up for the new era of AI, and the autonomous driving system-on-chips, or SoC, in 2018. These innovations have significantly contributed to the company's growth and its position as a leader in the field of accelerated computing.

The company's investment in research and development has also enabled it to support several multi-billion-dollar end markets with the same underlying technology, using a variety of software stacks developed either internally or by third-party developers and partners. This has strengthened NVIDIA's ecosystem and increased the value of its platform to its customers.

NVIDIA's research and development efforts are focused on creating unique value for the markets it serves, bringing together hardware, systems, software, algorithms, libraries, and services to create a unified underlying architecture. This approach has allowed the company to address diverse computing requirements and support various applications, including artificial intelligence, data analytics, and scientific computing.

NVIDIA is headquartered in Santa Clara, California, and was incorporated in California in April 1993, before being reincorporated in Delaware in April 1998, indicating a connection to the state of California.

The company's location in California suggests it is part of the state's thriving technology industry, with access to a large talent pool and innovative ecosystem, which could contribute to its growth and development in the field of AI and computing.

NVIDIA's systems, including GPUs and data center-scale accelerated computing platforms, are used by the world's leading cloud service providers and consumer internet companies to enable and accelerate services such as AI solutions, search, and online shopping, ultimately delivering to billions of end users.

The company's accelerated computing platforms are utilized by enterprises and startups across various industries, including enterprise software, transportation, healthcare, and financial services, to build new AI-enabled products and services or to accelerate workloads and workflows.

NVIDIA's computing solutions, including GPUs and networking, support over 3,500 applications and power more than 75% of the supercomputers on the global TOP500 list, aiding in important applications such as simulating molecular dynamics, climate forecasting, and materials science.

The company's systems, specifically GPUs, are chosen by gamers for immersive gaming experiences and are also used by professional artists, architects, and designers for creative and design use cases, such as visual effects and building design, accelerated by NVIDIA's GPUs and software platform.

NVIDIA has built full software stacks that run on top of their GPUs and CUDA to bring AI to the world's largest industries, including NVIDIA DRIVE stack for autonomous driving, Clara for healthcare, and Omniverse for industrial digitalization, and introduced the NVIDIA AI Enterprise software, an operating system for enterprise AI applications.

The company's software solutions are used by enterprises and startups across a broad range of industries to build new generative AI-enabled products and services, or to dramatically accelerate and reduce the costs of their workloads and workflows, including the enterprise software industry for new AI assistants and chatbots.

NVIDIA's computing solutions are used by researchers and developers to accelerate a wide range of important applications, from simulating molecular dynamics to climate forecasting, with support for more than 3,500 applications, and powers over 75% of the supercomputers on the global TOP500 list.

The company's software platform is used by professional artists, architects, and designers for a range of creative and design use cases, such as creating visual effects in movies or designing buildings and products, and generative AI is expanding the market for their workstation-class GPUs.

Nvidia Corp. utilizes a fabless and contracting manufacturing strategy, partnering with key suppliers for all phases of the manufacturing process, including wafer fabrication, assembly, testing, and packaging. The company relies on the expertise of industry-leading suppliers certified by the International Organization for Standardization in areas such as fabrication, assembly, quality control, and testing.

The company's suppliers are responsible for procuring most raw materials used in the production of Nvidia's products, allowing Nvidia to focus on product design, quality assurance, marketing, and customer support. However, in periods of growth, Nvidia may place non-cancellable inventory orders for certain product components in advance of historical lead times or pay premiums to secure future supply and capacity.

Nvidia has expanded its supplier relationships to build redundancy and resilience in its operations, providing long-term manufacturing capacity aligned with growing customer demand. The company's supply chain is concentrated in the Asia-Pacific region, with foundries such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited (TSMC) and Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd. producing its semiconductor wafers. Additionally, Nvidia purchases memory from suppliers like Micron Technology, Inc. and SK Hynix Inc.

By partnering with suppliers, Nvidia can avoid significant costs and risks associated with owning and operating manufacturing operations. This strategy enables the company to maintain its focus on high-value activities while ensuring a stable and reliable supply of components for its products.

Nvidia Corp. mentions that they directly procure certain raw materials used in the production of their products, such as memory, substrates, and a variety of components, which are types of components. Nvidia Corp. emphasizes the importance of avoiding significant costs and risks associated with owning and operating manufacturing operations by employing a fabless and contracting manufacturing strategy, which allows them to focus on product design, quality assurance, marketing, and customer support for their components and products.

Nvidia Corp's computing platforms serve a diverse set of markets, including data centers, gaming, professional visualization, and automotive, indicating the company's broad market reach and the entity Professional Visualization is one of the key markets they operate in.

Nvidia's strategy of providing strong design support and pre-sales assistance to its partner network, including those in the professional visualization segment, is seen as key to improving time-to-market, customer satisfaction, and fostering relationships that encourage the use of their next-generation products, indirectly benefiting the Professional Visualization market.

groundings.text: The market for Nvidia's products is intensely competitive and is characterized by rapid technological change and evolving industry standards, with conformity to industry standard APIs being a key competitive factor.

Nvidia believes that its ability to remain competitive will depend on how well it is able to anticipate the features and functions that customers and partners will demand, including adherence to industry standards, and whether it is able to deliver consistent volumes of its products at acceptable levels of quality and at competitive prices.

The company notes that a significant source of competition comes from companies that provide or intend to provide products based on various technologies, including InfiniBand, Ethernet, Fibre Channel, and proprietary technologies, highlighting the importance of industry standards in the competitive landscape.
The company notes that software support is a principal competitive factor in the market for its products, highlighting the importance of software in its business.

Nvidia Corp. believes that its ability to remain competitive will depend on how well it can anticipate the features and functions that customers and partners will demand, including software-related demands.

The company faces competition from large cloud services companies with internal teams designing hardware and software that incorporate accelerated or AI computing functionality, such as Alphabet Inc., Amazon, Inc., and Microsoft Corporation, which highlights the role of software in the competitive landscape.

Nvidia Corp.'s competitors include suppliers and licensors of hardware and software for discrete and integrated GPUs, custom chips, and other accelerated computing solutions, including solutions offered for AI, such as Advanced Micro Devices, Inc., and Intel Corporation, which underscores the significance of software in the industry.

In October 2023, the USG announced new and updated licensing requirements for exports to China and Country Groups D1, D4, and D5, which includes some countries in the Middle East, such as Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, of Nvidia's products exceeding certain performance thresholds.

The Annual Report on Form 10-K for Nvidia Corp. outlines various risk factors that could harm the company's business, financial condition, results of operations, or reputation, potentially causing a decline in stock price. The report highlights risks related to demand, supply, and manufacturing, such as failure to estimate customer demand accurately, defects in products, and business disruptions. It also notes the potential impact of adverse economic conditions, international sales and operations, and climate change on the company's business.

The report emphasizes the importance of considering these risk factors in addition to other information in the Annual Report. It also notes that additional risks, trends, and uncertainties not presently known to the company or considered immaterial may also harm its business, financial condition, results of operations, or reputation.

groundings.text: The USG informed Nvidia of an additional licensing requirement for a subset of A100 and H100 products destined to certain customers and other regions, including some countries in the Middle East, during the second quarter of fiscal year 2024.

New and updated licensing requirements announced by the USG in October 2023 apply to exports to Country Groups D1, D4, and D5, which include countries such as Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates in the Middle East, for products exceeding certain performance thresholds, including A100, A800, H100, H800, L4, L40, L40S, and RTX 4090.

Nvidia Corp. notes that if regulators conclude the company has failed to fulfill commitments or violated applicable law in China, it could face penalties or restrictions on its business, having a material and adverse impact on its operations and financial condition.

The USG announced export restrictions and licensing requirements targeting China's semiconductor and supercomputing industries, which impact exports of certain chips, software, and hardware to China, including Hong Kong and Macau, specifically affecting Nvidia's A100 and H100 integrated circuits.

Nvidia Corp. is subject to licensing requirements for exporting products exceeding certain performance thresholds to China, including A100, A800, H100, H800, L4, L40, L40S, and RTX 4090, with the USG informing the company that these requirements are effective immediately for certain products.

Following export controls, Nvidia transitioned some operations out of China and Hong Kong, which could be costly and time-consuming, and may adversely affect research and development, supply and distribution operations, and revenue during any transition period.

Nvidia Corp. may seek licenses for customers requiring products covered by the licensing requirements, but the licensing process is time-consuming, and there is no assurance that the USG will grant such a license or act on the application in a timely manner, with the process lacking clear standards or an opportunity for review.

The Notified Advanced Computing (NAC) process has not resulted in approvals for exports of products to customers in China, indicating a significant challenge for Nvidia's business operations. The license process for exports to certain countries has been time-consuming and has resulted in license conditions, disproportionately impacting Nvidia and potentially hindering its competitiveness.

Nvidia's products are subject to new restrictions and licensing requirements, which may harm the company's competitive position and future results. The management of these new licenses and other requirements is complicated and time-consuming, and further changes in US export controls could negatively impact Nvidia's business and financial results.

The licensing requirements may benefit certain competitors, as the licensing process will make Nvidia's pre-sale and post-sale technical support efforts more cumbersome and less certain. This could encourage customers in China to pursue alternatives to Nvidia's products, including semiconductor suppliers based in China, Europe, and Israel.

The USG has changed and may again change the export control rules, potentially subjecting a wider range of Nvidia's products to export restrictions and licensing requirements. This could negatively impact Nvidia's business and financial results, and the company may be unable to sell its inventory of affected products or develop replacement products not subject to licensing requirements.

Export controls may disrupt Nvidia's supply and distribution chain for a substantial portion of its products, which are warehoused in and distributed from Hong Kong. Additionally, export controls restricting the sale of datacenter GPUs may also negatively impact demand for Nvidia's networking products used in servers containing its GPUs.

The USG has changed and may again change the export control rules, which could subject a wider range of NVIDIA's products to export restrictions and licensing requirements, negatively impacting the company's business and financial results in various markets, including the Middle East.

In the event of such change, NVIDIA may be unable to sell its inventory of certain products and may be unable to develop replacement products not subject to the licensing requirements, effectively excluding the company from all or part of the China market, as well as other impacted markets, including the Middle East.

Export controls may disrupt the company's supply and distribution chain for a substantial portion of its products, which are warehoused in and distributed from Hong Kong, and this disruption could also affect sales to markets outside China, including the Middle East and Europe.

The Notified Advanced Computing, or 'NAC,' process has not resulted in approvals for exports of products to customers in China, indicating challenges in the export license process. This has a disproportionate impact on NVIDIA, potentially disadvantaging it against competitors who sell products not subject to the new restrictions or can acquire licenses for their products.

The USG's export controls, including those targeting China, may be changed at any time, further subjecting NVIDIA's products to export restrictions and licensing requirements. This could negatively impact NVIDIA's business and financial results, potentially excluding it from the China market and other impacted markets, including the Middle East.

The licensing requirements may benefit certain competitors, as the licensing process will make NVIDIA's pre-sale and post-sale technical support efforts more cumbersome and less certain. This could encourage customers in China to pursue alternatives to NVIDIA's products, including semiconductor suppliers based in China, Europe, and Israel.

The USG has already imposed conditions to limit the ability of foreign firms to create and offer large-scale GPU clusters, including imposing license conditions on the use of products to be exported to certain countries. This could disrupt a significant portion of NVIDIA's supply and distribution chain and negatively impact sales of products to markets outside China, including the US and Europe.

The US government's export controls may negatively impact demand for NVIDIA's products in China, and excessive or shifting controls could encourage customers to 'design-out' US semiconductors, including NVIDIA's, to reduce compliance burden and risk, ultimately harming NVIDIA's business and financial results.

Restrictions imposed by the Chinese government on gaming activities and access to games may adversely affect NVIDIA's Gaming revenue, while increased oversight of digital platform companies could also negatively impact NVIDIA's Data Center revenue in China.

The Chinese government may impose restrictions on the sale of NVIDIA's products or products containing components made by NVIDIA's partners and suppliers, such as the announced restrictions on certain sales of products containing Micron-made components, which could negatively impact NVIDIA's business and financial results.

NVIDIA's business depends on consistent and reliable supply from overseas partners, especially in Taiwan, and any new restrictions that negatively impact this supply could harm NVIDIA's business and financial results, including its ability to serve the Chinese market.

Concerns about Nvidia Corp.'s practices, particularly with regard to the collection, use, retention, security, or disclosure of personal information, could damage its reputation and adversely affect its operating results, even if such concerns are unfounded.

The California Consumer Privacy Act of 2018, as amended by the California Privacy Rights Act of 2020, or CPRA, gives California residents the right to access, delete and opt-out of certain sharing of their personal information, and to receive detailed information about how it is used and shared. This law provides for fines of up to $7,500 per intentional violation and created a private right of action for certain data breaches.

Nvidia Corp. notes that the exercise of rights under the CPRA, such as the right to access, correct, or delete certain personal data, and to opt-out of certain data processing activities, may impact its business and ability to provide products and services in California.

groundings.text: Nvidia Corp. has implemented certain infrastructure, systems, policies, and procedures to address circumstances such as cybersecurity incidents, including processes for assessing, identifying, and managing material risks from cybersecurity threats, which are integrated into its overall risk management systems and processes.

The expected realized gains and losses deferred into accumulated other comprehensive income or loss related to foreign currency forward contracts within the next twelve months was not significant.

The company had outstanding inventory purchase and long-term supply and capacity obligations totaling $16.1 billion as of January 28, 2024, reflecting commitments to purchase components used to manufacture its products.
The inventory purchase obligations are part of the company's total future purchase commitments, which amount to $20.707 billion as of January 28, 2024, with $17.316 million due in fiscal year 2025.

The company enters into agreements with contract manufacturers that allow them to procure inventory based on criteria defined by the company, with options to cancel, reschedule, and adjust requirements based on business needs prior to firm orders being placed.

The accrual for product warranty liabilities related to inventory was $306 million as of January 28, 2024, and $82 million as of January 29, 2023, indicating a significant increase in estimated warranty liabilities.

The company's inventory-related commitments and contingencies are managed through various agreements and provisions, including long-term supply and capacity agreements, and are disclosed as part of its overall financial obligations.

groundings.text: The Consolidated Financial Statements of Nvidia Corp. include estimated product returns and warranty activity, with a balance at the beginning of the period of $82 million in 2024, $46 million in 2023, and $22 million in 2022. Additions to product warranty liabilities were $278 million in 2024 and $145 million in 2023, primarily related to the Compute & Networking segment.

The Consolidated Financial Statements also disclose indemnities provided for matters such as tax, product, and employee liabilities, as well as intellectual property indemnification provisions in technology-related agreements with third parties. However, maximum potential future payments cannot be estimated due to the lack of a maximum stated liability in many agreements.

Nvidia Corp.'s Consolidated Financial Statements reflect the company's involvement in litigation, including a putative securities class action lawsuit and a derivative lawsuit. The securities class action lawsuit was initially dismissed, but a Ninth Circuit panel reversed the dismissal in part, and Nvidia has filed a petition for a writ of certiorari in the Supreme Court of the United States.

The company's Consolidated Financial Statements are subject to the outcome of these legal proceedings, which may materially affect financial performance or require changes to business operations. Nvidia has not recorded any liability in its Consolidated Financial Statements for the indemnifications provided.

The Consolidated Financial Statements provide a comprehensive overview of Nvidia Corp.'s financial position, including its product warranty liabilities, indemnifications, and litigation. The statements are an essential part of the company's 10-K filing, providing stakeholders with critical information about its financial health and potential risks.

groundings.text: The Consolidated Financial Statements of Nvidia Corp. present the tax effect of temporary differences that give rise to significant portions of the deferred tax assets and liabilities. As of January 28, 2024, the gross deferred tax assets were $8.0 billion, with a valuation allowance of $1.55 billion, resulting in total deferred tax assets of $6.45 billion.

The Consolidated Financial Statements report deferred tax liabilities, including unremitted earnings of foreign subsidiaries, operating lease assets, and acquired intangibles, totaling $831 million as of January 28, 2024. The net deferred tax asset was $5.62 billion.

Nvidia Corp.'s Consolidated Financial Statements disclose the company's intention to indefinitely reinvest approximately $1.1 billion and $250 million of cumulative undistributed earnings held by certain subsidiaries in Israel and the United Kingdom, respectively. The company has not provided the amount of unrecognized deferred tax liabilities for temporary differences related to these investments.

The Consolidated Financial Statements note that as of January 28, 2024, Nvidia Corp. had U.S. federal, state, and foreign net operating loss carryforwards of $315 million, $342 million, and $361 million, respectively. The company also had federal research tax credit carryforwards of $31 million and state research tax credit carryforwards of $1.6 billion.

The Consolidated Financial Statements provide information on the expiration of net operating loss carryforwards, with the federal and state carryforwards beginning to expire in fiscal years 2026 and 2025, respectively. The foreign net operating loss carryforwards of $361 million may be carried forward indefinitely.

Nvidia Corp. has a significant amount of deferred tax assets related to research and development expenditures, with $3,376 million and $1,859 million as of January 28, 2024, and January 29, 2023, respectively. The company also has research and other tax credit carryforwards of $936 million and $951 million for the same periods.

The company's research and development expenses are impacted by tax credits, with federal research tax credit carryforwards of $31 million as of January 28, 2024, which will begin to expire in fiscal year 2025. Additionally, Nvidia has state research tax credit carryforwards of $1.6 billion, primarily attributable to the State of California.

Nvidia's income tax expense is affected by its research and development activities, with a tax benefit of $187 million and $189 million for the fiscal years 2023 and 2024, respectively. The company's effective tax rate is influenced by its global operations and research and development investments.

The company's consolidated financial statements reflect the tax effects of temporary differences related to research and development expenditures, with a net deferred tax asset of $5,617 million as of January 28, 2024. This includes long-term deferred tax assets of $6.1 billion and long-term deferred tax liabilities of $462 million.

The company is subject to taxation by taxing authorities in China, with the significant tax jurisdictions that may be subject to examination including China for fiscal years 2005 through 2023. As of January 28, 2024, the company is currently under examination in China for these fiscal years.

Nvidia Corp. notes that it is subject to taxation in multiple countries, including China, and that tax authorities in these jurisdictions may examine the company's tax positions. The company has accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits, which may be affected by the outcome of these examinations in China and other countries.

The company's tax attributes, including those related to China, remain subject to audit and may be adjusted for changes or modifications in tax laws or other facts and circumstances. Utilization of these tax attributes may also be subject to limitations due to ownership changes and other limitations provided by the Internal Revenue Code and similar foreign tax provisions, including those in China.

The Consolidated Financial Statements of Nvidia Corp. include notes on tax jurisdictions under examination, such as Germany, India, Israel, and Taiwan, for fiscal years 2005 through 2023. The company also outlines its capital return program, which includes share repurchases and cash dividends to shareholders.

The Consolidated Financial Statements detail the company's share repurchase program, which aims to offset dilution from shares issued to employees. As of January 28, 2024, the company was authorized to repurchase additional shares of its common stock up to $22.5 billion. The company also paid cash dividends to its shareholders, with $395 million, $398 million, and $399 million paid in fiscal years 2024, 2023, and 2022, respectively.

The Consolidated Financial Statements provide information on the company's employee retirement plans, including tax-qualified defined contribution plans for eligible employees in the US and certain other countries. The company's contribution expense for these plans was $255 million, $227 million, and $168 million for fiscal years 2024, 2023, and 2022, respectively.

The Consolidated Financial Statements include segment information, with the company's Chief Executive Officer reviewing financial information on an operating segment basis. The company's segments include Compute & Networking and Graphics, with each segment including various products and services, such as data center accelerated computing, gaming GPUs, and virtual GPU software.

The Consolidated Financial Statements note that operating results by segment include costs or expenses directly attributable to each segment, as well as costs or expenses allocated between the two segments. The 'All Other' category includes expenses not assigned to either Compute & Networking or Graphics for purposes of making operating decisions or assessing financial performance.
